- More than one playable character for story mode (Unlocks after completing easy mode first)
-Change the health regeneration system so theres actual health pick-ups (This helps to make the game feel less empty)

Writing, art, music & story: Awesome

Gameplay: garbage.

I'll give the devs A for effort, but in the end, gameplay for a sidescrolling beat-em-up is just horrible if you grew up on stuff in their heyday from the NES/SNES/Sega/Arcade era. Same with killing normal mobs it just doesn't feel as visceral killing destroying them compared to games from over 25 years ago.

This may sound like an oxymoron givel that it's pixel art, but this game is a good example of developers that put graphics over gameplay, and it's a real shame given the game world's novelty potential.

Verdict: even though I got the game as part of a bundle, I couldn't even slog through 10 minutes of it. Sorry devs, but you guys didn't do your homework. You've really got to raise the bar given the history of the medium. I've played free flash games that are more fun than this. Do better QA & Testing next time.

reviewText:
Overall I had a great time with Fist Of Awesome. I laughed and tapped my foot through every level, and immediately started my second play through on a higher difficulty after finishing the game. This game has the perfect blend of great art and music style, humor and fluid game play, and one of the best credit theme songs of all time. Fist Of Awesome is priced perfectly and left me with a smile on my face and nostalgia in my heart. This is a great indie title and has earned 7.5 out of 10 from me.

STORY
The story of Fist Of Awesome is a timeless tale about a lumberjack called Tim Burr, who must fight his way to the truth, and set right the timeline that has seen his home destroyed and his family taken from him. Tim is empowered with the mighty Fist Of Awesome, a talking hand that guides his travels through the damaged timelines searching for the cause of the temporal disturbance. Along his journey Tim must face off against super advanced bears, deer and buffalo who due to the timeline alterations have risen to be the dominant power on Earth.

Fist Of Awesome's story is silly, but that is what I fight Bears was aiming for, and each funny one liner, pop culture reference or throw back to old school gaming is so perfectly delivered that the player will have a great time and laugh right through to the end. The fist play through of the story will take the average gamer no more than an hour to complete but with this in mind I was not disappointed by the playtime, and instead finished the game feeling that I had a great bit of fun getting there.

GAMEPLAY
Fist Of Awesome's controls will be instantly familiar to anyone who has spent some time playing side scrolling fighting games and are easy to get the hang of. The combat is basic in concept but as enemies become more resilient in the higher levels a degree of strategy is required to progress. Each time zone Tim progresses through culminates in a boss fight which is started off with some funny dialogue and are a decent challenge to the player.
Tim gains points and levels up throughout the stages depending on the combos the player can land, and is able to allocate one point to life, strength, speed or special per level. I had a great time with the general game play and leveling system, with the only let down being that enemy types were a bit too samey, and didn‚Äôt use their type specific attacks often enough.

VISUALS & MUSIC
The 8-bit art and music style of Fist Of Awesome is brilliant, and further enhances the comedy of the game. I found each level to be entertaining and beautiful in its own way, and enjoyed the well paced soundtrack throughout this crazy adventure.

reviewText:
Fist of Awesome has its fine features as well as its drawbacks. What you should know going in though is you should be getting it for about 70% story and 30% actual gameplay. Yes it's a side-scrolling beat-em-up, and yes we desperately need more good games along those lines. Fist of Awesome doesn't quite live up in my opinion.

Well why the hell am I recommending it? Because for the price to entertainment value the game is totally worth it. It's funny, and it has a challenge mode that's actually kinda challenging. In general the fighting is pretty clunky, and it's not terribly hard to abuse the setup to win pretty much any fight if you're patient about it. Enemies will all fall for the same dumb tricks. If you're like me and as impatient as all get-out, then the game's challenge goes up a bit and it feels a little more rewarding to clear a stage. The graphics are that retro-throwback nostalgia-style that's so dominant in indie titles these days, but it's done well, and the writing is at the right level where sitting down with a beer, hooking up the gamepad, and playing through can make for a pleasant couple of hours.

The biggest drawbacks are the few I've mentioned: clunky fighting and not really challenging. The other big drawback is a lack of multiplayer. Even if it was just local co-op, I'd be happy. Side-scrollers are the kind of thing you want to get together with friends to grind your way through, laugh, and chew the fat over. While I can enjoy this kind of game on my own, I like the option of having a friend or two along for the ride. Comedies are always funnier when there's someone else in the room to laugh with.

reviewText:
Not sure how many hours of game time this game will offer, but after a bit of play time, it certainly does not disappoint.(However, after 30 minutes of play time, I have completed half of the levels seen in the trailer)

I expected a simple beat-em-up and got a complex and intricate fighting system, fine-tuned by years of balance testing and realistic movement mechanics exhibited by bears. Is that bear really in the game, or real life? What is the exact scenario that would happen if I was to fight a bear under incredibly realistic circumstances? Fist of Awesome has answered, and this is the best bear fighting simulator I have seen all year.

And the story is incredibly deep, too. Never have I ever cried, or been so touched by the Tim Burr's struggle for humanity, and the fights he faces with his own demons, with whom he must also fight alongside. The supporting characters play an astounding plot-central role that no other written genius could ever deliver, on paper, movie, or game. This game leaves me with a deep connection to the characters and has inspired me to help deliver humanity from this terrible fate. Truly amazing.

TLDR
If you want a good laugh, buy the game.

reviewText:
Fist of Awesome belongs to the same genre/category as Street of Rage, so it has many similarities. You walk your character down a street/road and beat your way through enemies.  When you get knocked down, it takes a moment to get back up, When you do a jump-kick, enemies are guaranteed to be knocked down. When you clear a zone of enemies, you move on to the next zone.  There are differences, such as regenerating health, a special fist attack, and increasing character stats, that add a bit of twist to the game, all of which are welcome features.

The strongest part of the game is the humor - a world where the food chain has been alternated such that bears are at the top and the humans are the food, and the hero that will save the day is a lumberjack with a talking fist sidekick. The dialogue is great and the background art that reflects the absurdity of the world is a nice detail that adds to the humor.

Unfortunately, the game is not without flaws. First, the game becomes a slug-fest. The enemies have increasingly larger amount of health with each level, making each kill more of a hassle later on in the game. If you make the mistake of leveling too much stats that aren't related to damage, you're in for a long game.  Even at max damage, combos still take a while to wear one down and there will be many enemies in each level. Second, while there are a nice variety of enemies to fight in terms of appearance, they have a limited amount of skills.  Skill sets of enemies are rehased so by the half-way point into the game, you've probably seen them all.  Furthermore, bosses are all the same, except different in appearance, health, and damage output. Once you fight the first boss, you'll know how to fight the last one. Third, surprisingly there aren't any droppable items. No guns, swords, bats, brooms, chain saws, power-ups, nothing. It feels like a missed opoportunity given the humor of the game and could've added more variety to the combat that becomes stale later on in the game. Lastly, there's the absence of co-op for a Street of Rage type of game, and having it would've definitely helped with the issue of the tankiness of the enemy by having a friend beat them down as well.

Ultimately, while Fist of Awesome does well in the humor department, it is a bit lacking in the gameplay. Even if the enemies remain tanky, additions such as items and co-op could've made the game much more appealing. The game is recommended if you're into the humor and looking for a Street of Rage type of game.  The shortness of the campaign means you will probably make it to the end of the game before being too bored by the combat. But if you do enjoy the combat or want to dive in and out of the game for short gameplay, it offers an arena mode.

reviewText:
I'm not quite sure what most people were expecting going in to this from some of the reviews that I have seen. This is not a AAA title by any means, and doesn't try to be, so please do not expect that. No it doesn't have the best graphics... But the game delivers on every level that it promises:

Does it have constant bear puns? - Yes
Does the story represent bears taking over the world and a lumberjack saving humanity? - Yes
Do you get to punch bears? - Yes
Does it pay tribute to Streets of Rage, Double Dragon and Final fight? - Yes
Would this be enjoyed more by people with/or that admire beards? - Quite possibly

Yes it does get very repetitive, but for anyone who enjoyed these types of games in the 80s and early 90s this was a gameplay staple. It may lack the special police car attack from Streets of Rage, but it improves upon the somewhat one note (but favored classic) Double Dragon in terms of controls, gameplay and in my opinion story as well. The game also features an interesting health mechanic of auto healing. Being a fan of the games I have mentioned previously I did not approve of this choice initially. However I came to welcome this feature due to the constant barrage of enemies, and with that the rapidly expanding enemy health bars. The XP gain and upgrade system is also a nice little addition and adds more flavor, but does not seem critical.

In closing, I do really enjoy this game. The otherwise mind numbing, repetitive beat em up genre offers just enough bear puns and beard fanaticism to entertain. Please also keep in mind that back in the day for a game like Final Fight you would expect to pay $50+ to own it on Super Nintendo... I was able to purchase this as part of a Humble Bundle for $1, and in all fairness I believe it is worth more.

For what it is (and for what it wants to be) I give it 3 beards and a soul patch out of 5.

The visual theme, graphics and general game play are bare bones typical beat-em-up. You'll find yourself generally using the same attacks against each foe with the occasional jump thrown in to the mix. A simple level up system is added in which adds some depth, as well as multiple characters and unlockables.

However, all of that is irrelevant; Fist of Awesome's appeal and charm lies in it's humourous storytelling. The world is thrown into an alternative timeline where bears are the dominant species, armed with the Fist of Awesome, a super powered talking...fist, you set out to unravel the mystery and restore the original timeline. Along the way your adventure is packed full of comical backdrops, tooltips and enemies. The banter between Fist of Awesome and the lumberjack hero ranging from Puns, Wit, Meta-humour, even to somewhat crude observations.

If that doesn't appeal to you, one of the main features of the game is; You get to punch bears in the face.
Before playing i hadn't realised that this was one of my life goals. But i achieved it all the same and it still draws me back with the incentive of being able to punch bears in the face.
